intro: Paepalanthus serralapensis, commonly known as the Laramie sedge, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the Cyperaceae family, which includes sedges and grass-like plants. The plant typically grows in moist, well-drained soils in open habitats such as meadows and grasslands. It has slender, triangular stems and produces small, greenish-white flowers in clusters. Its botanical features make it an important component of native plant communities in its range.
